comments.body: I love the idea, it doesn't even have to be hieroglyphics, it can be the letters that you see in the enchantment table.

It would be cool if they added underground tombs found by digging up sand in the desert or a Mesa, and the hieroglyphics told you where they were, and when you got to the tomb a Pharaoh spirit type mob would be guarding it and you have to kill it, The mob would give you something called “Scroll of Secrets” to tell you where treasure was hidden in the tomb. In the casket of where the Pharaoh was buried would be a mummy and it would come alive if you disturbed it. And the treasure could be diamonds, emeralds, gunpowder, treasure maps, and maybe even Pharaoh armor and weapons.

You can like use a scissor or something like that and then click on a sand block to make hieroglyphs and hieroglyphs spawns in the desert temple, VOTED!

The mechanics and appearance of the Jungle Temple and Desert Pyramid were nice, but could use a revamp. The Woodland Mansion shows that large structures can be generated also.

Jungle Temple Changes: 

These were made to house deities, as well as bury their kings.

  • Make it larger - more rooms and passages to explore (ideally underground);
  • Add more secret passages - these passages could lead to traps, secret rooms, or even used as safe paths;
  • Add more traps - fall pit, lava drop, arrow dispenser hallway, etc;
  • Puzzle door - door could be opened by flipping certain levers throughout the temple in order to open it to gain access to the Treasure Room;
  • Treasure Room - this room would be outfitted with numerous simple traps (treasure chest would be a trapped chest);
  • Enemy Spawners - each Jungle temple should have at least one zombie villager spawner inside of it to fit the feel of the temple.

Desert Pyramid Changes:

Pyramid's were made to be the burial place for king's & queen's.

  • Make it big - pyramids are very large, and this should reflect that;
  • Add secret passages - these passages could lead to traps, secret rooms, or even used as safe paths;
  • Add more traps - final resting places were meant to be protected;
  • Tomb Room - these (two) rooms (King Tomb & Queen Tomb) would have items such as boats, gold, food, weapons, and more. They would also feature a sarcophagus in each tomb;
  • Enemy Spawners - each desert pyramid should have at least one husk spawner inside of it.
I believe the outside structure should remain the same while the traps / halls should be randomized

I just had this same idea. I have been playing the same world since beta. And my problem with that is when there is an update that has added new whatever over the years I have to adventure out so far from my original home to find the new stuff that was added. If there were portals that could be link to other worlds when a big update comes out I could start a new world portal find what is needed then return to my world with it. Best idea ever!

Yes I agree with drewacula76, I have 64 worlds on Pocket Edition, 11 on Nintendo Switch, and 50 on Java Edition, 1 on XBOX, and 3 on PS4. But, I only use one world. Where all my friends built really cool houses and we progressed so much. And I adventured out so much that when a new update comes, I’m going to have travel long distances to find something new. (Especially with this nether update coming soon). So I really do need to connect my worlds that I haven’t adventured far on. So I have an idea. You make a nether portal, and just like the Minecraft April Fools Snapshot, you right into a book and throw it into the nether portal, but for it to work you must throw in a book with the name of your world on the book and boom!!!!!! I see my other world. But I don’t think Mojang might want this in there game...

 

Your idea was amazing

This is a great idea! My son has this idea this morning and I went to submit it and found this. Think about how cool it would be to connect your favorite worlds. All those places where you painstakingly created things could all be connected! I wholeheartedly agree with this idea. I am a software engineer and though I understand this could be technically difficult it doesn't mean that it isn't worth it.

Yeah! Gravel should generate in cave ceilings more frequently.

I find gravel generates in the ceilings a lot, but I don't know if that's a difference between Java and Bedrock world generation (I play Bedrock).  I don't think there should be a new collapse mechanic, and I don't think gravel should be even more common in Bedrock.

Remember that doing things underground is more than just caving and mining.  Some people build their bases underground, and that would be very much disrupted by a random "cave-in" mechanic.

@ClayGoddessSari It seems like gravel does generate in the cave ceilings much more often in Bedrock Edition. I couldn't find anything about it being intentional, but it should also be in Java Edition.
I think you need to change mineshafts. You need to make them look more technolical and add a new kind of villager working at Mineshafts!

Or randomised areas of 'cracked stone' which becomes a gravity block when it touches a player.

It would be broken slightly quicker than stone, and would have a chance of dropping as an item when it hits the cave floor.

Only picked up using silk touch.
Imagine if you mine too much on cave , it starts to crumble by particles fall upon you and ceiling starts to fall down. Mojang hear this

I kind of agree, but not quite... Whilst the general idea is cool, the way you put it is just... Yeah, a few points make it non-minecraft-ish (I understand updates are made to change the game, but we can't ruin some people experiences), but the idea of a collapsing cave is interesting.

Perhaps the "vibratons" would be able to disturb both gravel/sand piles and snow in mountains? It would make caving harder, even more if it brought something of value that can only be obtained by exploring the collapsing caves... Gravel could generate arroound them, making it harder to use any other strategy other than good ol' caving (If it was a bolck it oblygatorilly would generate facing "air"). Imagine the tension you would go trought if you were caving looking for that something, trying not to disturb the mortal trap above your head...

TL;DR: good idea, though I think there are better ways of executing it.

Rather than having mines that the player digs collapsing, which I think would ruin the game for many players for a number of reasons, I’d rather it be that naturally occurring caves have certain blocks that when mined would trigger a collapse. I’d like it if when a support block (unrecognizable from other blocks?) were mined, some ominous sound effects of collapse would trigger and it would cause several other blocks to fall (dropping items or not—perhaps, flint?). After mining several of these hidden “support” blocks, the cave (or portion thereof) would collapse.
Sounds a lot like underwater ruins...  No need for land/water duplicates.
